title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where?

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes

title: Art & Design Juried Exhibition
description:
Montclair State University’s Department of Art and Design is excited to kick off the Spring 2026 semester with the  Art & Design  Juried Exhibition  at Finley Gallery . The exhibition runs from January 21 through January 30, 2026, with an opening reception on Wednesday, January 21 from 2-4pm.  
   
 This showcase features work from students in Visual Arts, Fashion Design and Merchandising, Illustration, Product Design, and Visual Communication Design, and Art Education programs. Eighty-four professors across five disciplines selected one student from each of their course sections, highlighting exceptional projects that demonstrate the creativity and potential cultivated in our studios.  
   
 The exhibition demonstrates the breadth and scope of our programs, and gives our community a wonderful opportunity to see what is being made and discovered in our studios here at Montclair State University.  
   
 Don’t miss this opportunity to experience the incredible talent and innovation of Montclair State University’s Art and Design students. 
   
 Art & Design  Juried Exhibition 
 Finley Gallery, Finley Hall 
 Exhibition dates: 1/21 - 1/30 
 Opening Reception: Wed. 1/21 2-4pm

title: Higher Education (MA) Virtual Information Session
description:
Build your career in Higher Education    
 Whether you're already working in  higher ed  or looking to break into the field, our flexible program is designed to meet you where you are - and help you go even further. 
 We're hosting a  virtual information session on January 29  at 6:00 PM . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to meet our team and determine if our program fits your goals. 
 Our coursework offers a broad focus on administration and leadership, preparing students for a variety of roles in higher education. The curriculum integrates organizational and social science perspectives and explores key administrative and programmatic issues.

description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and with open arms! 
 This event will be a fun night full of food, fellowship, and games! 
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Montclair State Mainstage Opera "DIE ZAUBERFLÖTE"
description:
Montclair State  Mainstage Opera & University  Symphony Orchestra  
   
 presents 
 DIE ZAUBERFLÖTE 
 Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart,  Composer 
 Emanuel Schikaneder,  Librettist 
 Janine Morita Colletti, Director Kyle Ritenauer, Conductor 
 Valentina Cannao,  Scenic & Costume Design 
 David Orlando,   Lighting Design 
 Lili Federico,  Multimedia/Projection Design 
 Maxine Steinman,  Choreographer 
 Paige Elise Buchanan Stewart,  Livestream Production 
   
 Alexander Kasser Theater 
 Saturday, January 31 @ 8:00 PM  Tickets Sunday, February 1 @ 3:00 PM  Tickets   
   
 
 
 A dragon to be vanquished. A magic flute that conquers hearts. A queen whose rage blazes among the stars. A secretive order holding the power of the sun. 
 
 
 One of the most beloved operas of all time, Mozart’s  Die Zauberflöte  ( The Magic Flute ) is a dazzling adventure where fairy tale, comedy, and timeless wisdom meet.  With music that soars from the hilarious to the sublime, it enchants audiences of all ages. 
 Follow Prince Tamino and Princess Pamina as they brave trials of fire, water, and silence in their search for love and enlightenment. Laugh with the irrepressible bird-catcher Papageno, and be swept away by the Queen of the Night’s blazing vengeance and show-stopping arias. Beneath its fantastical surface lies a story of courage, compassion, and the triumph of harmony over darkness. 
 Join us for an unforgettable journey of magic, music, and imagination. 
 Sung in German • Spoken dialogue in English (Janine Morita Colletti)

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Dr. Darian Clonts Voice Faculty Recital + Lecture
description:
Faculty Recital + Lecture 
 Spirituals: Songs Birthed in Bondage, Sung Across Boundaries 
 Darian Clonts, tenor with  Mary Pinto, piano 
 Sunday, February 1 | 8:00 PM Leshowitz Recital Hall John J. Cali School of Music, Montclair State University 
 This faculty recital and lecture on Spirituals, presented by  Darian Clonts , invites audiences into a thoughtful exploration of how singers can ethically and responsibly perform this uniquely powerful and authentically American repertoire. 
 The evening will feature a performance by Dr. Clonts alongside select undergraduate students from the Cali School of Music, combining live music with critical reflection on history, context, and interpretation. Through performance and commentary, the program examines Spirituals as songs born from bondage that continue to resonate across cultural and musical boundaries. 
 Dr. Clonts is an active performer across opera, gospel, and art song, with appearances at Cincinnati Opera, The Atlanta Opera, The Princeton Festival, and Indiana University Opera Theater. He currently serves on the voice faculty at the John J. Cali School of Music at Montclair State University and William Paterson University, maintains a private studio, and lectures nationally on opera and African American music. 
 Open to the public. For more information, visit  montclair.edu/music .

title: Art Forum featuring Ellen Harvey
description:
The Department of Art & Design presents the Spring 2026 Art Forum series. Art Forum is a speaker series featuring artists, designers, art historians, curators, and art critics from around the world presenting their work and ideas in an open forum.   
   
 Artist Ellen Harvey kicks off this engaging series, sharing her creative process, research, and insights into her latest work.   
   
 Ellen Harvey is a British-born conceptual artist whose work ranges from guerrilla street interventions like her iconic New York Beautification Project for which she painted miniature landscapes over New York’s graffiti sites to immersive institutional installations and large-scale public artworks. Her work is painting-based but utilizes a wide variety of media and participatory strategies to explore several reoccurring themes such as the social and ecological implications of the picturesque, the revolutionary potential of nostalgia, the conflict between advertising and ornament in public space, the relationship between art and tourism and the role of art and the artist in our society. 
   
 Harvey’s work frequently centers the viewer, allowing members of the public to actively participate by submitting their ideas. For The Utopia Machine she has been painting patent drawings based on utopias submitted by members of the public. Her other on-going project The Disappointed Tourist, for which she has been painting lost sites suggested by members of the public, formed the centerpiece of a survey show that recently travelled to various countries. 
   
 Her latest, installation The Disappointed Tourist is currently on view at the Chicago Architecture Center. Her new outdoor installation Winter in the Summer House is currently on view at Olana. Ellen lives and works in Brooklyn and is represented by Locks Gallery (Philadelphia) and Meessen Gallery (Brussels, Belgium). 
   
 This speaker series is free and open to the public. 
   
 📅 Art Forum 
 Monday, 2/2/26  5:20pm-7pm 
 Calcia Hall, Room 140

title: MARKETS AND THE REPUBLIC: THE POLITICAL ECONOMY OF AMERICAN DEMOCRACY
location: Presentation Hall (College of Communication and Media)
description: The relationship between American democracy and capitalism is complex – ranging from antagonistic to symbiotic. Tracing this relationship from the founding era through major economic transformations, social movements, and political reforms, this lecture examines how markets have both supported and strained democratic ideals of equality, liberty, and self-government. The lecture will consider pivotal debates over regulation, labor, innovation, and inequality, highlighting moments when democratic institutions reshaped capitalism – and when economic power challenged democratic accountability. Participants will be invited to reflect on what this evolving relationship means for the future of democratic governance in the United States.

title: Skills for Success: The Truth About Soft Skills
description:
Think success in college and beyond is all about technical know-how? Think again! This interactive workshop uncovers the real power of soft skills—like communication, teamwork, problem-solving, conflict resolution, and adaptability—that employers and professors alike value most. Through hands-on activities and real-world examples, you’ll learn how to recognize, strengthen, and showcase these essential skills to thrive as a student and future professional. 
 Event Details: 📅 Date: Tuesday, February 3, 2026 🕒 Time: 2 - 3 pm 📍 Location: Susan A. Cole Hall, Suite 340 (3rd Floor) 
 Presented by the University College Academic Programming Team. This event is open to all University College (pre-major) students. 
 There will be complimentary food.

description:

title: Celebrate alumni at the opening reception of Carpe Diem: Select Alumni in the Visual Arts
location: George Segal Gallery, 4th Floor of the Red Hawk Deck
description:
Admission is free, open to the public.  Learn more about this exhibition 
   
 Celebrate Montclair State University alumni at the opening of the exhibition  Carpe Diem: Select Alumni in the Visual Arts.  Remarks by Jonathan GS Koppell,  President , and Rita Walters,  Vice President for Development and Alumni Engagement  at 6 pm. 
   
 Carpe Diem: Select Alumni in the Visual Arts  is a group exhibition presented by the Office for Development and Alumni Engagement and hosted by the University Galleries.  Carpe Diem  brings together twelve accomplished alumni working in a range of media. 
   
 Curated by Sally Morgan Lehman, who has taught in the Department of Art and Design at Montclair and is owner and director of Morgan Lehman Gallery in New York City,  Carpe Diem  highlights the breadth of artistic practices fostered at Montclair and the lasting impact of its visual arts alumni. 
   
 Featured artists include Flávia Berindoague ’13, Bisa Butler ’05, Jonathan Calm ’97, Kyle Coniglio ’10, Alyssa Fanning ’12, Allen Ginsberg (1943), Márta Kucsora (2005–06), Michael Manning ’11, Nancy Bergman Pantirer ’80, Tiffany Perez ’09, William Pope.L ’78, and Maria Valdivia ’24.

title: Civic MatchMaker Tabling
description:
Swipe Right on Your Civic Voice! 
 Have you ever wanted to better understand your own views—and how they align with politics, public policy, and civic life?  Civic Matchmaker  is a fun, welcoming, and low-pressure tabling experience designed to help you explore what matters most to you and how those values connect to the world around you. 
   
 Stop by to answer a few quick, interactive “match-style” prompts that highlight your priorities on issues like education, social justice, the economy, healthcare, climate, and community well-being. As you make your selections, you’ll see how your perspectives align with broader civic and political themes—helping demystify politics and make it feel more personal and relevant. 
   
 ✨  What to Expect: 
 
 
 Engaging, easy-to-answer prompts focused on values and issues 
 
 
 A snapshot of how your views align with civic and political topics 
 
 
 Opportunities to learn how people turn values into action 
 
 
 Nonpartisan resources to help you stay informed and involved 
 
 
 A relaxed, judgment-free space to ask questions and explore 
 
 
   
 No debates. No pressure. Just meaningful self-reflection, discovery, and conversation. Whether you’re deeply engaged or just starting to figure out where you stand,  Civic Matchmaker  helps you connect your values to civic life—and take the next step toward using your voice with confidence. 💬🗳️

title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.

title: Soundtracks of the Culture (Black Music Through the Years)
description:
Soundtracks of the Culture: Black Music Through the Years is a celebration of the powerful evolution of Black music and its impact on culture, identity, and social movements. This experience takes participants through key musical eras, beginning with The Roots (1920s–1940s) featuring blues, jazz, and gospel, moving into Revolution (1950s–1970s) where music fueled activism and change, continuing through The Culture (1980s–2000s) highlighting the rise of hip-hop and rap, and ending with Now & Next (2010s–Today) showcasing modern sounds shaping today’s generation. 
 Join us for a journey through sound, history, and influence as we explore how Black music continues to inspire, empower, and define culture across generations.

title: 2026 Class Gift Tabling - Information and Philanthropy Cord Pick-Up
description:
Each year, our graduating class participates in a proud Class Gift tradition where members of the class invest in the University by supporting areas of Montclair State University that are most important to them. We invite the Class of 2026 to come together to show your support! 
 All gifts to Montclair count! Make your gift to any area of campus you feel most passionate about – such as the Emergency Book Fund, The Red Hawk Pantry, your school or college, The Fund for Montclair State or athletic program. 
 Your gift will pay it forward for future Red Hawks and kick-start your philanthropic connection to Montclair. 
 
 Commemorate your class year! Make a gift of at least  $20.26  and you’ll receive your customized philanthropy cord to wear over your commencement robe.  
 For a gift of  $40 , celebrate this milestone with your family, friends and colleagues by having your message displayed on the screen at the Commencement you will be participating in, and receive a customized philanthropy cord. 
 
 How do I get my customized philanthropy cord? 
 Customized philanthropy cords will be available for pick-up: 
 
 Tuesday, October 28 from 1:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Thursday, November 20  from 1:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Tuesday, December 2 from 12:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Bloomfield Campus Graduation Fair: Wednesday, December 10th from 12:00 – 6:00 p.m. in Deacon’s Den, Talbott Hall  (for Bloomfield graduates only) 
 Montclair Campus Graduation Fairs: Thursday, December 11th from 10:00 a.m. – 7:00 p.m. in the Student Center Ballrooms  (for Montclair or Bloomfield graduates) 
 
 Graduates can also arrange to pick up their philanthropy cords in the Overlook Corporate Center, 150 Clove Road, Little Falls, NJ during business hours, Monday through Friday, 8:30 a.m. – 4:30 p.m. Philanthropy cords can also be mailed to those who cannot pick it up. The last day we will mail the cords is Monday, December 22, 2025 at 2:30 p.m. Please contact James Stewart, Associate Director of Annual Giving at stewartj@montclair.edu or 973-655-5328 to finalize options to get your cords for the Winter Commencement. 
 Every student has benefitted from donor generosity to areas of academic support, emergency funding for students and overall priorities to boost students’ success every day. Thank you for paying it forward! For more information, please contact James Stewart, Associate Director of Annual Giving, at 973-655-5328 or stewartj@montclair.edu.

title: Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art and Design is excited to announce the opening of the  Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition . Students' work will be on view at the Finley Gallery from February 5 through February 19 with the opening reception on Wednesday, February 11 from 2pm-4pm.  
   
 This exhibition features original design illustrations and presentation layouts from courses in the Fashion Design and Merchandising program, including Fashion Illustration, Digital Applications for Fashion, Flat Pattern, and Draping. 
   
 Students design, create, develop, and prepare 2D original visuals that can become 3D professionally executed looks. The fashion design students develop original illustrations to demonstrate their extensive design knowledge by using programs Adobe Illustrator and Adobe Photoshop in tandem with traditional illustration and rendering techniques by hand.  
   
 Each work selected depicts the range of creative possibilities utilizing the process of fashion design. title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Nikki Abissi Brass Masterclass
description:
Nikki Abissi Brass Masterclass 
 Friday, February 6, 2026 | 2:00 PM Room 201, Chapin Hall Montclair State University 
 Join acclaimed trombonist  Nikki Abissi  for an inspiring brass masterclass focused on building a sustainable, fulfilling career in music. Drawing on her wide-ranging experience as an orchestral musician and performer, Abissi will explore the many professional paths available to today’s musicians and offer practical insight on preparing to thrive beyond school. 
 Abissi is Second Trombonist of the American Symphony Orchestra and has performed with many of the country’s leading ensembles, including the New York Philharmonic, on Broadway, and with the Radio City Orchestra. She previously held positions with the Alabama Symphony, Colorado Symphony, and Macon Symphony, and was a fellow with the New World Symphony. She earned her Bachelor of Music from The Juilliard School and her Master of Music from Stony Brook University. 
 Free and open to the public. Presented by the  John J. Cali School of Music , Montclair State University.

title: Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art and Design is excited to announce the opening of the  Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition . Students' work will be on view at the Finley Gallery from February 5 through February 19 with the opening reception on Wednesday, February 11 from 2pm-4pm.  
   
 This exhibition features original design illustrations and presentation layouts from courses in the Fashion Design and Merchandising program, including Fashion Illustration, Digital Applications for Fashion, Flat Pattern, and Draping. 
   
 Students design, create, develop, and prepare 2D original visuals that can become 3D professionally executed looks. The fashion design students develop original illustrations to demonstrate their extensive design knowledge by using programs Adobe Illustrator and Adobe Photoshop in tandem with traditional illustration and rendering techniques by hand.  
   
 Each work selected depicts the range of creative possibilities utilizing the process of fashion design. From the initial steps of conception to a sketch, from an illustration to brand & product development, and finally garment construction, students showcase their creative voices as the emerging talent and future of the fashion apparel industry. 
   
 Come view and support the work of Fashion’s next generation of designers and creatives! 
   
 FASHION ILLUSTRATION AND DIGITAL APPLICATIONS EXHIBITION

title: Magnificent Bird / Book of Travelers | Two Song Cycles written and performed by Gabriel Kahane
description:
Experience two distinct works by acclaimed songwriter and performer Gabriel Kahane in one unforgettable day.  
   
 In this duo of intimate solo musical plays, composer Gabriel Kahane blends songwriting and storytelling for a singular, poignant theatrical event. Book of Travelers recounts the strangers he met on a 9,000-mile train journey through a divided America, and Magnificent Bird chronicles a year he spent entirely off-line, and the unexpected turbulence of living quietly. Performed on alternating nights, these two concept albums offer a relentless self-inquiry, and a searing portrait of a world in flux.  To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesday - Thursday, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK. 
   
 Hailed as “one of the finest songwriters of the day” by The New Yorker, Gabriel Kahane is a musician and storyteller whose work spans the theater, club, and concert hall. Highlights of the 2024-25 season include a return to the New York stage in a production at Playwrights Horizons, performances at the Philharmonie de Paris, Wigmore Hall, and the Concertgebouw with fellow composer/performer Caroline Shaw, the premiere of a clarinet concerto for Anthony McGill, a solo debut with the Orchestre National de Lyon, and Kahane’s San Francisco conducting debut in Carla Kihlstedt’s Twenty-six Little Deaths. Kahane's collaborators range from Phoebe Bridgers, Paul Simon, Sufjan Stevens, and Sylvan Esso, to the Danish String Quartet, Roomful of Teeth, and Attacca Quartet. As a writer, he has been published by The New Yorker online and The New York Times; a newsletter and collection of essays on music, literature, and politics can be found at  gabrielkahane.substack.com . 
   
 4:00 pm Magnificent Bird 
 Run Time:  74 minutes, no intermission. 
   
 Magnificent Bird, is an intimate reflection on a year of self-imposed isolation during which the artist set out to write a song every day. With contributions from Andrew Bird, Chris Thile, Amelia Meath (Sylvan Esso), and Pulitzer Prize- winning composer Caroline Shaw, this collection explores the delicate balance between personal introspection and global crises. It’s a vivid musical snapshot of life during a tumultuous period, offering both a personal and universal meditation on modern-day existence. Based on Kahane’s fifth LP. 
   
 7:00 pm - Book of Travelers 
 Run Time:  70 minutes, no intermission 
   
 In Book of Travelers, Gabriel Kahane embarks on a journey across the United States, exploring the intersections of American identity and personal connection through the people he meets along the way. This powerful and emotional piece blends folk, classical, and pop influences to create a nuanced reflection on contemporary life in America. The work is a poignant and intimate exploration of what it means to traverse a country at a crossroads.

title: Love at First Vote "Why I Vote"
description:
What makes someone fall in love with voting?  Love at First Vote: Why I Vote  is an interactive, student-centered event that invites participants to reflect on their personal motivations, values, and experiences that shape why voting matters to them. Whether it’s your first time engaging with civic life or you’re a regular voter, this event centers real stories, personal connection, and the power of participation. 
   
 Through three engaging stations, students will explore the  why  behind voting—moving beyond the ballot to understand how civic participation connects to identity, community, and change. All are welcome, and no prior knowledge is required. 
   
 ❤️ Event Stations 
   
 1. Why I Vote Wall 
 Students are invited to write or select prompts explaining why they vote (or why they plan to). Responses are displayed on a shared wall, creating a collective snapshot of the diverse motivations and values across campus. 
   
 2. Find Your Issue Station 
 Participants explore key issues—such as education, healthcare, climate, housing, and social justice—and reflect on which ones motivate them most. This station helps students connect personal priorities to civic action. 
   
 3. Your Voting Story Station 
 A storytelling-focused space where students can read short “Why I Vote” stories from peers, alumni, and community members, and share their own experiences or hopes for the future of democracy. 
   
 ✨  Love at First Vote  creates space for reflection, conversation, and connection—reminding us that voting isn’t just a civic duty, it’s personal.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Brief Description:

 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up?

 When and Where?

title: Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art and Design is excited to announce the opening of the  Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition . Students' work will be on view at the Finley Gallery from February 5 through February 19 with the opening reception on Wednesday, February 11 from 2pm-4pm.  
   
 This exhibition features original design illustrations and presentation layouts from courses in the Fashion Design and Merchandising program, including Fashion Illustration, Digital Applications for Fashion, Flat Pattern, and Draping. 
   
 Students design, create, develop, and prepare 2D original visuals that can become 3D professionally executed looks. The fashion design students develop original illustrations to demonstrate their extensive design knowledge by using programs Adobe Illustrator and Adobe Photoshop in tandem with traditional illustration and rendering techniques by hand.  
   
 Each work selected depicts the range of creative possibilities utilizing the process of fashion design. From the initial steps of conception to a sketch, from an illustration to brand & product development, and finally garment construction, students showcase their creative voices as the emerging talent and future of the fashion apparel industry. 
   
 Come view and support the work of Fashion’s next generation of designers and creatives! 
   
 FASHION ILLUSTRATION AND DIGITAL APPLICATIONS EXHIBITION 
 Finley Gallery, Finley Hall 
 Exhibition dates: 2/5-2/19 
 Opening Reception: 2/11 2pm-4pm

title: Art Forum with Sally Morgan Lehman
location: George Segal Gallery, 4th Floor of the Red Hawk Deck
description:
Admission is free, open to the public.  Learn more about this exhibition 
   
 Art Forum  is a speaker series featuring artists, designers, art historians, curators, and art critics from around the world presenting their work and ideas in an open forum, hosted by the Department of Art & Design. Curator Sally Morgan Lehman will lead a walkthrough of the exhibition  Carpe Diem: Select Alumni in the Visual Arts. 
   
 Carpe Diem: Select Alumni in the Visual Arts  is a group exhibition presented by the Office for Development and Alumni Engagement and hosted by the University Galleries.  Carpe Diem  brings together twelve accomplished alumni working in a range of media. 
   
 Curated by Sally Morgan Lehman, who has taught in the Department of Art and Design at Montclair and is owner and director of Morgan Lehman Gallery in New York City,  Carpe Diem  highlights the breadth of artistic practices fostered at Montclair and the lasting impact of its visual arts alumni. 
   
 Featured artists include Flávia Berindoague ’13, Bisa Butler ’05, Jonathan Calm ’97, Kyle Coniglio ’10, Alyssa Fanning ’12, Allen Ginsberg (1943), Márta Kucsora (2005–06), Michael Manning ’11, Nancy Bergman Pantirer ’80, Tiffany Perez ’09, William Pope.L ’78, and Maria Valdivia ’24.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Immersive Residency Program Cali Midweek Series with PAQUITO D’RIVERA
description:
Cali Immersive Residency Program Cali Midweek Series: Cali Conversation and Performance with PAQUITO D'RIVERA and Cali School of Music Jazz Studies Area Coordinator Dr. Oscar Perez Leshowitz Recital Hall, Chapin Hall, Cali School of Music FREE – Reservations Suggested 
 CUBAN-AMERICAN SAXOPHONIST AND CLARINETIST Cali Immersive Residency Program On Campus: FEBRUARY 9–13, 2026 
 Full Immersive Residency Schedule 
 Paquito D’Rivera  is a celebrated Cuban-born clarinetist, saxophonist, and composer whose genre-defying career spans Latin jazz, classical music, and beyond. Winner of 16 Grammy and Latin Grammy Awards, he was a founding member of Irakere and Dizzy Gillespie’s United Nation Orchestra, and has recorded over 40 solo albums. A child prodigy and son of classical saxophonist Tito Rivera, he has performed with major orchestras worldwide and composed for top ensembles including Yo-Yo Ma and Imani Winds. Also a writer and producer, D’Rivera is known for his eclectic style and for championing Latin musical traditions on the global stage.

title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.

title: Spanish Writing Center -Workshop Series - Online - February 2026
organization: Center for Latino Heritage & Spanish Language Excellence
description:
How to Use Subjunctive with Verbs & Expressions of Emotions 
 This workshop offers a clear and practical introduction of the subjunctive, with special attention of its use with emotive verbs. Through examples and exercises, it explains when and why the subjunctive is used, and compares it with the use of the indicative, highlighting the changes in meaning depending on the verbs. Ideal for students who want to strengthen their understanding and use of the subjunctive in real contexts.

description:
Visiting the Pantry:

title: Fireside Chats
description:
Hang out and have casual conversations with other students while enjoying refreshments! Join us on Thursdays from 3:15-4:15pm.  
 What are Fireside Chats: 
 
 A space for students to meet, connect, and have a casual conversation about a given topic, or anything else that feels comfortable for everyone else. It can be about the school climate, student life in general, or your favorite show. All students are welcome!

title: Civic MatchMaker Tabling
description:
Swipe Right on Your Civic Voice! 
 Have you ever wanted to better understand your own views—and how they align with politics, public policy, and civic life?  Civic Matchmaker  is a fun, welcoming, and low-pressure tabling experience designed to help you explore what matters most to you and how those values connect to the world around you. 
   
 Stop by to answer a few quick, interactive “match-style” prompts that highlight your priorities on issues like education, social justice, the economy, healthcare, climate, and community well-being. As you make your selections, you’ll see how your perspectives align with broader civic and political themes—helping demystify politics and make it feel more personal and relevant. 
   
 ✨  What to Expect: 
 
 
 Engaging, easy-to-answer prompts focused on values and issues 
 
 
 A snapshot of how your views align with civic and political topics 
 
 
 Opportunities to learn how people turn values into action 
 
 
 Nonpartisan resources to help you stay informed and involved 
 
 
 A relaxed, judgment-free space to ask questions and explore 
 
 
   
 No debates. No pressure. Just meaningful self-reflection, discovery, and conversation. Whether you’re deeply engaged or just starting to figure out where you stand,  Civic Matchmaker  helps you connect your values to civic life—and take the next step toward using your voice with confidence. 💬🗳️

title: Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art and Design is excited to announce the opening of the  Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition . Students' work will be on view at the Finley Gallery from February 5 through February 19 with the opening reception on Wednesday, February 11 from 2pm-4pm.  
   
 This exhibition features original design illustrations and presentation layouts from courses in the Fashion Design and Merchandising program, including Fashion Illustration, Digital Applications for Fashion, Flat Pattern, and Draping. 
   
 Students design, create, develop, and prepare 2D original visuals that can become 3D professionally executed looks. The fashion design students develop original illustrations to demonstrate their extensive design knowledge by using programs Adobe Illustrator and Adobe Photoshop in tandem with traditional illustration and rendering techniques by hand.  
   
 Each work selected depicts the range of creative possibilities utilizing the process of fashion design. From the initial steps of conception to a sketch, from an illustration to brand & product development, and finally garment construction, students showcase their creative voices as the emerging talent and future of the fashion apparel industry. 
   
 Come view and support the work of Fashion’s next generation of designers and creatives! 
   
 FASHION ILLUSTRATION AND DIGITAL APPLICATIONS EXHIBITION 
 Finley Gallery, Finley Hall 
 Exhibition dates: 2/5-2/19 
 Opening Reception: 2/11 2pm-4pm

title: I AM | Camille A. Brown & Dancers
description:
Five-time Tony nominated choreographer and director Camille A. Brown deepens her explorations of Black joy in Camille A. Brown & Dancers’  I AM . With captivating live and original music,  I AM  launches new queries into the possibilities of imagination—and boldly investigates the future. Inspired by a narrative within HBO’s  Lovecraft Country  and the rhythms of the movie  Drumline , Brown’s 2025 New York Times Critics’ Pick breaks boundaries and “takes her signature interweaving of African diasporic dance forms to new heights.” —  The New York Times 
   
  To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesdays and Thursdays, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK.

title: Be CAST's Valentine
description:
CAST wants to show their love and has a Valentine for you! 
 Attend any CAST service on February 12th or 13th and stop by the tutoring center front desk to receive a Valentine from CAST. 
 Students looking for academic support for their classes can attend both appointments and walk in services.  
 Academic Support available in: 
 Peer Tutoring : Meet with our student tutors for a one on one tutoring session based on your specific classes for the semester. Appointments can be in person in the Sprague Library, our Dinallo tutoring room or virtually through zoom. Appointments can be booked in  Navigate . 
 Supplemental Instruction :   Weekly peer-led review sessions for historically challenging courses . Supplemental Instruction leaders are embedded in the classrooms and offer no appointment needed, group visits. Schedules can be found in  Navigate  or on our website. 
 Peer Academic Coaching :  Talk with our coaches about the tools for success in your college classes and build an individualized plan for your own, time management, note taking and study strategies. 
 Workshops : Attend our workshops to learn more about resources on campus and tips for academic success. Workshops are offered both in person and virtually. 
   
 Schedules and locations for all tutoring can be found in  Navigate  and our Workshops on  Engage

title: Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art and Design is excited to announce the opening of the  Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition . Students' work will be on view at the Finley Gallery from February 5 through February 19 with the opening reception on Wednesday, February 11 from 2pm-4pm.  
   
 This exhibition features original design illustrations and presentation layouts from courses in the Fashion Design and Merchandising program, including Fashion Illustration, Digital Applications for Fashion, Flat Pattern, and Draping. 
   
 Students design, create, develop, and prepare 2D original visuals that can become 3D professionally executed looks. The fashion design students develop original illustrations to demonstrate their extensive design knowledge by using programs Adobe Illustrator and Adobe Photoshop in tandem with traditional illustration and rendering techniques by hand.  
   
 Each work selected depicts the range of creative possibilities utilizing the process of fashion design. From the initial steps of conception to a sketch, from an illustration to brand & product development, and finally garment construction, students showcase their creative voices as the emerging talent and future of the fashion apparel industry. 
   
 Come view and support the work of Fashion’s next generation of designers and creatives! 
   
 FASHION ILLUSTRATION AND DIGITAL APPLICATIONS EXHIBITION 
 Finley Gallery, Finley Hall 
 Exhibition dates: 2/5-2/19 
 Opening Reception: 2/11 2pm-4pm

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: 2026 Black Alumni Advisory Council Black History Month Career Panel
location: University Hall 1050 - Ingrid & Scott Williams Lecture Hall
description:
Heirs and Architects of a Great Legacy: Black History Month Alumni Event 
 In partnership with the African American Caucus and the African American Studies Department at Montclair State University, this special Black History Month event celebrates our history while providing tools to elevate your career. Join us for a unique opportunity to connect and network with accomplished alumni across diverse industries, united by the strength of family and community legacy. Hear from a panel of professionals who will share valuable insights to guide your career journey. Let their stories inspire and empower you to take your next step forward. 
 Event Details 🗓  Date:  Monday, February 16 ⏰  Time:  4 – 6:30 p.m. 📍  Location:  University Hall 1050 - Ingrid & Scott Williams Lecture Hall 💰  Cost:  FREE 📝  Registration:  Required (Sign up now!) 
   
 What’s in it for you? 
 
 Career Panel featuring alumni in the social services, business and the sciences 
 Networking with professionals who’ve been where you are, and who are now empowering others with their knowledge 
 Tips for launching your career and navigating your next steps 
 Direct access to alumni who are crushing it in their fields, showing the power of roots and wings in action 
 
   
 Meet the Panelists - TBD 
   
   
   
 What is BAAC? The Black Alumni Advisory Council (BAAC) connects Montclair State University alumni to current students to share knowledge, offer mentorship, and amplify social justice and inclusion in the community. We honor the strength of our shared roots while supporting the rise of empowered futures. 
 . 
 
   
 What is the African American Caucus of Montclair State University? 
 Awareness, Advocacy, and Change  The African American Caucus (AAC) of Montclair State University serves as a forum for discussion and advocacy regarding matters and issues important to faculty, staff, and students of African descent at Montclair State University. 
   
 What is African American Studies? 
 The African American Studies Minor is an interdisciplinary program.  Students examine the contributions people of African descent have made to human and world history. Courses critically analyze a wide range of philosophies, cultural experiences, social issues, leadership models and solutions to social problems. The program builds on the African American Studies scholar-activist tradition. Students explore education as a means not only for creating personal success but for developing stronger societies rooted in respect for diversity and human rights. 
   
 Got questions? Contact  The Office of Alumni Engagement at alumni@montclair.edu or 973-655-4141 
 This is your chance to level up your career game – don’t miss it!

title: Preparing to Defend Your Dissertation
description:
Designed for doctoral candidates approaching the final stages of their program, this session outlines the dissertation defense process from start to finish. Topics include defense eligibility, required approvals and forms, formatting and submission requirements, and final Graduate School deadlines. Students will also learn what to expect before, during, and after the defense. Who should attend:  Doctoral candidates preparing for their dissertation defense or final submission requirements. 
 Please register for the event through  this link .

 Registration is required in advance. This workshop is closed to the general public and open only to members of recognized Greek-letter and Social Fellowship organizations.

title: upLIFT
description:
Step into the brand-new PLAE Room and discover upLIFT—a judgement-free program designed to help every student, from complete beginners to seasoned gym-goers, feel confident and capable with free-weight training. Learn proper lifting technique, get personalized form checks, and master the basics of creating your own effective workout programs. Whether you’re looking to meet other students who love to lift, pursue new fitness goals, or simply feel more at home in the weight room, upLIFT offers a supportive community and a dedicated space to grow. The program is structured for steady progression throughout the semester, but you’re welcome to drop in anytime and join at your own pace. 
   
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 No registration required 
 FREE for students with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Beginning February 3, ending April 23 
 Tuesdays 3 PM - 4 PM, Wednesdays 6 PM - 7 PM, and Thursdays 2 PM - 3 PM

title: Rooted in Power
description:
A Civic Engagement Tabling Experience 
   
 Rooted in Power  is an interactive tabling event that invites students to explore where their power comes from—and how their values, identities, and lived experiences shape their role in civic life. Grounded in the idea that lasting change begins at the roots, this event encourages reflection, conversation, and connection around personal and collective power. 
   
 Through engaging prompts and hands-on activities, students will examine the issues they care about most, how those issues connect to their communities, and the ways civic participation—like voting, advocacy, and dialogue—can turn values into action. Whether you’re deeply engaged or just beginning to explore your civic voice, Rooted in Power meets you where you are. 
   
 ✨  What to Expect: 
 
 
 Interactive prompts to reflect on values, identity, and community 
 
 
 Opportunities to explore how personal experiences connect to civic power 
 
 
 Nonpartisan resources to learn how change happens at the local level 
 
 
 A welcoming, judgment-free space for conversation and curiosity 
 
 
   
 Rooted in Power  reminds us that power isn’t just something we see—it’s something we grow, nurture, and use together.

title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.

title: Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art and Design is excited to announce the opening of the  Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition . Students' work will be on view at the Finley Gallery from February 5 through February 19 with the opening reception on Wednesday, February 11 from 2pm-4pm.  
   
 This exhibition features original design illustrations and presentation layouts from courses in the Fashion Design and Merchandising program, including Fashion Illustration, Digital Applications for Fashion, Flat Pattern, and Draping. 
   
 Students design, create, develop, and prepare 2D original visuals that can become 3D professionally executed looks. The fashion design students develop original illustrations to demonstrate their extensive design knowledge by using programs Adobe Illustrator and Adobe Photoshop in tandem with traditional illustration and rendering techniques by hand.  
   
 Each work selected depicts the range of creative possibilities utilizing the process of fashion design. From the initial steps of conception to a sketch, from an illustration to brand & product development, and finally garment construction, students showcase their creative voices as the emerging talent and future of the fashion apparel industry. 
   
 Come view and support the work of Fashion’s next generation of designers and creatives! 
   
 FASHION ILLUSTRATION AND DIGITAL APPLICATIONS EXHIBITION 
 Finley Gallery, Finley Hall 
 Exhibition dates: 2/5-2/19 
 Opening Reception: 2/11 2pm-4pm

title: 2026 Legislative Breakfast: Human Trafficking at the Intersection of Sports
description:
Join us for the 4th Annual Legislative Breakfast  as Montclair State University convenes leaders, advocates, and the campus community to confront human trafficking in New Jersey and explore pathways for real change. 
 Now in its fourth year, the Legislative Breakfast brings together policymakers, survivor leaders, academics, students, and community partners for timely, solutions-oriented conversations at the intersection of research, policy, and practice. This is a unique opportunity for the MSU community to engage directly with issues shaping law, advocacy, and prevention efforts across the state. 
 This year’s theme,  “Human Trafficking at the Intersection of Sports,”  examines the often-overlooked risks connected to major sporting events. From labor exploitation in construction, hospitality, and event operations to increased vulnerabilities during large-scale tournaments, the conversation moves beyond headlines to focus on evidence-based policy responses and accountability. 
 Last year’s sold-out breakfast featured nationally recognized experts, survivor leaders, and New Jersey legislators—and this year’s program promises equally compelling dialogue and actionable insights. Students and staff alike are encouraged to attend, learn, and be part of a growing campus-wide commitment to prevention, awareness, and informed action. For any questions, please reach out to gcht@montclair.edu 
 
 
 
 
 -------------------------------------- Agenda 
 8:00 AM - 9:00 AM |  Registration Opens 
 9:15 AM - 9:45 AM |  Opening Remarks 
 9:45 AM - 10:15 AM |  4th Annual Smith/Wellstone Award Ceremony 
 10:15 AM - 10:30 AM |  Networking Break 
 10:30 AM - 11:45 AM |  Human Trafficking at the Intersection of Sports 
 11:45 AM - 12:30 PM |  Closing Remarks and Networking If you plan to attend the full event and would like a name badge,  please register on Eventbrite. This event is free and open to all.  ---- 
 This event is brought you by the Global Center on Human Trafficking at Montclair State University, along with its co-sponsors: - Montclair State University 
 
 College of Humanities and Social Sciences 
 Department of Justice Studies 
 Department of Social Work and Child Advocacy 
 Office of Government Relations 
 Department of Athletics 
 Department of Recreation 
 
 - It's a Penalty - Mission89 - Covenant House NJ - Family Service League - LSNJ - New Jersey Coalition Against Human Trafficking

title: Rent In Concert | Musical in Concert | Produced by AMP Worldwide
description:
Experience the iconic music of  RENT  like never before. In this sweeping symphonic concert produced by AMP Worldwide, a powerhouse ensemble of vocalists and instrumentalists brings Jonathan Larson’s groundbreaking rock musical to life in a sweeping symphonic concert. Featuring the full score—including “Seasons of Love,” “La Vie Bohème,” and “Take Me or Leave Me”—this electrifying performance celebrates the enduring spirit of love, loss, and chosen family. 
   
 Set in New York City’s East Village at the height of the HIV/AIDS crisis,  RENT  follows a group of young artists as they chase their dreams, navigate heartbreak, and fight to live—and love—fully in the moment. Winner of the Tony Award for Best Musical and the Pulitzer Prize for Drama,  RENT  remains a cultural touchstone with music that resonates across generations. 
   
 To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesdays and Thursdays, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK.

description:

title: All In: The Fight for Democracy
description:
Join us for a powerful screening of  All In for Democracy — The Stacey Abrams Story , a documentary that explores the modern fight for voting rights through the work and leadership of Stacey Abrams. The film examines the barriers to participation that persist in American democracy and highlights the grassroots organizing, advocacy, and resilience behind efforts to expand access to the ballot. 
   
 Through compelling storytelling and real-world examples, this screening invites viewers to reflect on the importance of civic participation, the impact of voter suppression, and the role individuals and communities play in strengthening democracy. Following the screening, participants are encouraged to engage in conversation and reflection around civic responsibility, equity, and democratic engagement. 
   
 This event is open to all and designed to foster learning, dialogue, and a deeper understanding of how democracy works—and how it can be protected and strengthened.

title: upLIFT
description:

Whether you’re looking to meet other students who love to lift, pursue new fitness goals, or simply feel more at home in the weight room, upLIFT offers a supportive community and a dedicated space to grow. The program is structured for steady progression throughout the semester, but you’re welcome to drop in anytime and join at your own pace.

title: Community and Social Services Career Expo
organization: College of Humanities and Social Sciences (CHSS)
description:
Community and Social Services Career Expo Date:  February 24, 2026 Time:  3:30pm-6:30pm Location:  University Hall Conference Center (7th Floor) 
 Pre-registration is strongly encouraged -  Register on Handshake ! 
 Calling all community and service-minded students exploring clinical and non-clinical career options! 
 Are you looking for a job or internship? Are you curious about the career paths you can pursue with your major or graduate program? If so, the Community and Social Services Career Expo is an amazing opportunity to meet employers that align with your professional interests. Whether you are a freshman or a graduate student, this event is designed to help you explore career possibilities, gain networking experience by talking with employers, and make connections that may eventually lead to a job or internship. There will be fun mixed in with the opportunity to win raffle prizes, and Rocky, Roxy, or Pebbles might even stop by! 
 More Information: - Visit with non-profit, government, and corporate employers that have a service-oriented mission - Discover opportunities with campus organizations and departments, including international experiences that incorporate social impact - Event details and employer list can be found on  Handshake . - Dress neatly and bring resumes! Check out Rocky's Closet for free professional attire. 
 This event is ideal for graduate and undergraduate students seeking jobs and internships in: Counseling, Child Advocacy, Justice Studies, Social Work, Political Science, Psychology and so much more! 
   
 Co-sponsored by:  College of Humanities and Social Sciences, College for Community Health, Office of Community Engagement and Partnerships, Office of Experiential Education and Career Connections, Office of Government Relations, Office of International Academic Initiatives 
   
 Questions? Contact Jennifer Dudeck-Lenis at  dudecklenisj@montclair.edu.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes

 Registration is not required

 When and Where?

title: upLIFT
description:
Step into the brand-new PLAE Room and discover upLIFT—a judgement-free program designed to help every student, from complete beginners to seasoned gym-goers, feel confident and capable with free-weight training. Learn proper lifting technique, get personalized form checks, and master the basics of creating your own effective workout programs. Whether you’re looking to meet other students who love to lift, pursue new fitness goals, or simply feel more at home in the weight room, upLIFT offers a supportive community and a dedicated space to grow. The program is structured for steady progression throughout the semester, but you’re welcome to drop in anytime and join at your own pace.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Brief Description:  
 Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: A Cross-Generational Conversation with Alumni Artists
location: George Segal Gallery, 4th Floor of the Red Hawk Deck
description:
Admission is free, open to the public.  Learn more about this exhibition 
   
 This multi-generational panel celebrates the distinguished women alumni of Montclair. Featuring exhibiting artists Nancy Bergman Pantirer ’80, Tiffany Perez ’09, and Maria Valdivia ’24 in conversation about their careers and creative practices, moderated by curator Sally Morgan Lehman. 
   
 Carpe Diem: Select Alumni in the Visual Arts  is a group exhibition presented by the Office for Development and Alumni Engagement and hosted by the University Galleries.  Carpe Diem  brings together twelve accomplished alumni working in a range of media. 
   
 Curated by Sally Morgan Lehman, who has taught in the Department of Art and Design at Montclair and is owner and director of Morgan Lehman Gallery in New York City,  Carpe Diem  highlights the breadth of artistic practices fostered at Montclair and the lasting impact of its visual arts alumni. 
   
 Featured artists include Flávia Berindoague ’13, Bisa Butler ’05, Jonathan Calm ’97, Kyle Coniglio ’10, Alyssa Fanning ’12, Allen Ginsberg (1943), Márta Kucsora (2005–06), Michael Manning ’11, Nancy Bergman Pantirer ’80, Tiffany Perez ’09, William Pope.L ’78, and Maria Valdivia ’24.

description: Ready to level up your Canva skills? This advanced workshop dives into powerful features like animations, brand kits, collaboration tools, and interactive content creation. title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.

title: INNOVATION NATION: KNOWLEDGE, DISCOVERY, AND THE AMERICAN EMERGENCE
location: Presentation Hall (College of Communication and Media)
description: Scientific inquiry, intellectual property and innovation have played a pivotal role in shaping America’s economic growth, security, and democratic aspirations. From early patent law and land-grant universities to federally funded research and the modern innovation economy, this lecture explores how public policy has structured incentives for discovery and dissemination of knowledge. Particular attention is given to universities as engines of research, talent development, and public purpose, operating at the intersection of academic freedom and national priorities. Participants will be asked to consider how evolving partnerships between government and higher education advance the common good and fuel America’s capacity for innovation.

title: Clinical Psychology (MA) Virtual Information Session
description:
Transform Lives With A Career In Clinical Psychology 
 Montclair's Clinical Psychology program combines advanced education with practical experience. Whether you’re interested in working in private practice or research, we’ll walk you through the wide range of career paths available for clinical psychology graduates. We offer two  STEM-Designated  concentrations within our rigorous Master's program, tailored to your unique practice objectives: 
 
 Clinical Psychology, Child/Adolescent Psychology Concentration (MA) Students in the child/adolescent concentration learn about the unique psychological needs of children and adolescents, as well as developmental considerations in psychopathology, assessment, and treatment, including the role of family and social contexts. This concentration is designed to prepare students for MA-level clinical positions in mental health settings, particularly those that serve children and families.    
 Clinical Psychology, Forensic Psychology Concentration (MA) The Forensic Psychology concentration is designed to prepare students to offer master’s level clinical services to legal system-involved populations in settings that do not require licensure. Such settings include mental health and drug court settings, offender rehabilitation programs, child and family advocacy settings and bona fide public service agencies exempted by state boards of psychological examiners for non-doctoral providers. 
 
 Ready to learn more? Join us for a  virtual information session on March 9 at 5:30 PM (EST)  to explore Montclair's programs in Clinical Psychology and speak directly with our faculty.

description: Join the Office of International Academic Initiatives to learn about the Study Abroad Opportunities that Montclair State University has to offer. title: Officer and Faculty Review – Session One
description: Please be aware of your scheduled review time and session. Review your email invite for the correct placement. We ask all SLC competitors to join us for a student and faculty review session. We will provide you with mock judging and guidance right before the State Leadership Conference to better aid you with judge expectations and provisions for last-minute adjustments.

title: Complexions eboard meeting
description: Complexions will be coming together to plan events and discuss this semesters galas.

title: Student Government Meeting
location: Bloomfield - Talbott Hall TM04 - Room of Excellence
description: Join the Student Government Association for a constitutional meeting where we discuss campus business including, but not limited to, programming events, community service initiatives, improvements of student life, leadership, and engagement. Welcome to all students, faulty, and staff. Your voice matters here on our campus. Great things happen in small rooms. Meet us in the  Room of Excellence  at  Talbott Hall ,  every other Monday  at  2pm .

title: Montclair Unraveled General Body Meeting!
description:
Do you want to learn a new knitting or crochet pattern? Do you want to make a cool craft but can't pick one or figure out where to start? Then come to Montclair Unraveled!  
 Join us and learn how to make something new like accessories, decor, or plushies! Already have something you're working on? Feel free to make some progress here! All are welcome, whether you have the most craft experience possible or none at all. Come by and enjoy the company of others who share your passions for the fiber arts!

title: Major & Career Exploration Talks: What We Wish We Knew Before Declaring!
description:
Not sure what major to choose or where your career path is headed? You’re not alone! Join us for Major & Career Exploration Talks: What We Wish We Knew Before Declaring!, a dynamic panel event where upperclassmen students share their real, unfiltered experiences about choosing their majors and navigating their career journeys. Hear firsthand what they wish they knew before declaring, the challenges they faced, and how they found their passions. Whether you're feeling undecided, overwhelmed, or just curious about different paths, this event will give you insights, inspiration, and practical advice to help you make informed decisions. Don’t miss this opportunity to gain valuable perspectives and take the next step in your academic and career journey! * Food and refreshments will be served! 
 Event Details: 📅 Date: March 17, 2026 🕒 Time: 2:30pm - 3:30pm 📍 Location: Student Center Underground (Rm 160) 
 Presented by the University College Academic Programming Team

title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.

title: Building Custom Course GPTs
description: In this workshop, educators will learn how to leverage Generative AI to create custom GPTs that scaffold student learning and support instructional goals. Through live demonstrations and guided practice, participants will learn to create custom GPTs that support authentic assessments, such as role-plays and case studies. The workshop will emphasize responsible and ethical AI use, highlighting how thoughtfully designed custom GPTs can enhance student engagement, support high-order thinking, and enable authentic, practice-based learning experiences. title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

title: Higher Education (MA) Virtual Information Session
description:
Build your career in Higher Education    
 Whether you're already working in  higher ed  or looking to break into the field, our flexible program is designed to meet you where you are - and help you go even further. 
 We're hosting a  virtual information session on March 19  at 6:00 PM . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to meet our team and determine if our program fits your goals. 
 Our coursework offers a broad focus on administration and leadership, preparing students for a variety of roles in higher education. The curriculum integrates organizational and social science perspectives and explores key administrative and programmatic issues.

title: Child Advocacy (MA) Alumni Perspectives: Advocating for Children in 2026
description:
Lead Change in Child Advocacy and Policy   When children and families face complex challenges, they need informed, compassionate professionals to stand up, speak out, and shape solutions. If you're ready to turn your commitment into action, we're here to help.  We're hosting a  virtual panel featuring alumni from our program on March 19 at 6:00 PM (EST) . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to hear directly from professionals who were once in your shoes and determine if our program fits your goals. This session will cover the following programs:  
 
 Online Master of Arts in Child Advocacy and Policy 
 Child Advocacy (Certificate) – Online 
 
 Why Montclair?  Completing the certificate program allows you to transfer all 15 credits towards the Master of Arts in Child Advocacy, in accordance with all related graduate policy.
